mirror: I purposely bought a good enough mirror to work from myself, for want of a model."

shoes: Van Gogh painted several still lifes of shoes or boots during his Paris period.
Van Gogh has placed the shoes within a specific spatial context: namely, the red-tile floor of the Yellow House.
this "still life of old peasants' shoes" may have been those of Patience Escalier, whose portrait Van Gogh executed around the same time, late summer 1888.

Van Gogh painted several still lifes of shoes or boots during his Paris period. Van Gogh has placed the shoes within a specific spatial context: namely, the red-tile floor of the Yellow House. This "still life of old peasants' shoes" may have been those of Patience Escalier, whose portrait Van Gogh executed around the same time, late summer 1888.

mosques churches: The symbols of the homeland remained lofty- where Jerusalem takes pride in the sanctity given to it by God, with its Mosques and Churches, grand by virtue of its history and heritage.

fully developed, sexually mature woman: this piece portrays her as a fully developed, sexually mature woman.

sexually mature woman: Mary, Mother of Jesus. Unlike the typical depiction of Mary as a fully clothed, chaste woman, this piece portrays her as a fully developed, sexually mature woman

ball gown: painting of an unidentified young woman in a ball gown
the trimmings on the woman's dress contribute to the highly dynamic feel of the painting
The painting depicts an unidentified young woman in a ball gown, and the trimmings on the woman's dress contribute to the highly dynamic feel of the painting.
vegetation: the dense vegetation serves as a protective shield, shutting out the external world and safeguarding the young woman's innocence and beauty
The dense vegetation serves as a protective shield, shutting out the external world and safeguarding the young woman's innocence and beauty.
pearl necklace: painting invites comparison to Mary Cassatt's Woman with a Pearl Necklace in a Loge, painted in the same year, which features a similarly attired woman seated in an upper-level box at the Paris Opera.

subject: subject appears apprehensive and distracted, as if she is waiting for someone before leaving the unknown event

virgin mary: The Virgin Mary is her daughter
jesus: Jesus is depicted as an infant
mountains: The religious scene is set in a fantastical mountainous landscape.
Leonardo used atmospheric perspective to create the illusion of the distant mountains.

lamb: lamb, a symbol associated with the Passion, hints to Christ’s destiny

virgin: The Virgin is seated broadly and holds the half-naked infant on her lap
The Virgin is seated broadly and holds the half-naked infant on her lap.
infant: holds the half-naked infant on her lap
The infant is held on her lap.
joseph: Joseph on the left is eclipsed by the two protagonists
He sits at an angle facing them, on a seat lower than the Virgin's
He looks up and focuses on a point somewhere outside the picture, as if reflecting on the words he has just read in the open book on his lap
He holds his reading glasses absent-mindedly and is clearly lost in thought
The portrayal of Joseph as a young and vigorous man, in contrast to the traditional elderly figure, is in line with the dictates of Counter-Reformationist principles

Joseph on the left is eclipsed by the two protagonists. He sits at an angle facing them, on a seat lower than the Virgin's. He looks up and focuses on a point somewhere outside the picture, as if reflecting on the words he has just read in the open book on his lap. He holds his reading glasses absent-mindedly and is clearly lost in thought. The portrayal of Joseph as a young and vigorous man, in contrast to the traditional elderly figure, is in line with the dictates of Counter-Reformationist principles.

He looks up and focuses on a point  somewhere outside the picture, as if reflecting on the words he has just read in the open book on his lap. He holds his reading glasses absent-mindedly and is clearly lost in thought. The portrayal of Joseph as a young and vigorous man, in contrast to the traditional elderly figure, is in line with the dictates of Counter-Reformationist principles.

edward iii: Edward III crossing the Somme is the first in the sequence and shows an incident preceding the Battle of Crécy, when the king was trying to cross the River Somme at Blanche Tache, near Abbeville, in order to escape the French army.
The king is on horseback just to the right of centre and the figures accompanying him can be identified with the aid of a key provided by the artist for George III.

Edward III crossing the Somme is the first in the sequence and shows an incident preceding the Battle of Crécy, when the king was trying to cross the River Somme at Blanche Tache, near Abbeville, in order to escape the French army. The king is on horseback just to the right of centre and the figures accompanying him can be identified with the aid of a key provided by the artist for George III.
english archers: dependent upon the skill of the English archers seen in the upper right of the composition.
The English archers are seen in the upper right of the composition, and the outcome of the battle was dependent upon their skill.
armour: For the historical narrative the primary sources in English were an early translation of the Chronicles (1325-1400) of Jean Froissart and the History of England (1754-62) by David Hume. french force: Edward III encountered and engaged a part of the French force under Godemar de Faye, the outcome of which, like the Battle of Crécy itself, was dependent upon the skill of the English archers seen in the upper right of the composition.

dining hall: The modest but clean setting of the women's dining hall serves as the backdrop for a touching human story that is revealed to us through the work's narrative title.
at the Pio Albergo Trivulzio, a retirement home in Milan founded in 1771 that housed more than eight hundred men and women by 1900.
